job_title: Vice President in Lake Success, NY
pros: Visionary CEO who challenges everyone to think outside the box and innovate.  Leaders who care about employees and want to ensure they are supported.  Great benefits and good compensation.  This is an organization that knows not everything is perfect, but sincerely wants to try and make things better throughout healthcare.  The mission and vision asks us all the care about the future of health, wellness and quality of life.  The teams i get to work with everyday are dedicated, loyal and willing to go the extra mile.  We rely on one another to get things done.  I have had many chances to make a difference.
cons: It is a big system and its complicated.  It is relationship centered and you need to value making friends and influencing people.  You need to be resilient and not give up when someone or something stops you.  It can be political and at times there are decisions made that aren't always clear as to why.   The senior leadership needs to get to know what's happening on the front lines and be more transparent.  More recognition is needed for wins along the way.  This is hard work and needs to be acknowledged.

review_title: Working in the Overlooked Portion of An Overall Excellent System
job_title: Research Assistant in Manhasset, NY
pros: As expected from a health network, they provide excellent care for their employees, and provide multiple opportunities for organized self-care and self-improvement.  Further, from what I have seen they are very accommodating to people from different walks of life and experiences.  Overall, the system as a whole cares for its employees and tries to make sure that they are happy and willing to work to the best of their abilities.
cons: The assumption is that everyone works in a patient-forward area, and when you don't this can slow things down and add considerable barriers to actually getting your work done.  The other major problem here is that if you work in one of the more specialized areas, like the research institute, then it is easy to feel like the upper echelons have forgotten about the institute as a whole, as it doesn't deal with patients directly.  Every bit of the administrational setup is designed for patient-focused areas, and this leaves something to be desired in other areas of the network.

job_title: Risk Management in Manhasset, NY
pros: The employees are hard working and generally competent.  Salary was reasonable market value BUT the work load and responsibility was TWICE that of comparable similar positions for the salary.
cons: Salary, though market value, was much too low for the level of responsibility and grossly unreasonable work load.  The work load was close to double that of similarly situated positions in New York, but salary the same as other institutions whose work load was half of that.  North Shore LIJ is unfortunately extremely demanding in their work load, never a moment to breath and have to scarf lunch down in 10 minutes (if at all), even going to the bathroom is difficult because of lost time due to the extremely unreasonable work load.  Management is horrible, bullying and abusive.  Every day someone is singled out by management for torture, abuse, yelling, threats - management takes their "discipline" beyond  anything acceptable, HR is aware but can't do anything about it (numerous complaints), and the higher-ups don't care so long as work is done on the ridiculous budget that makes management look good.  The yelling, screaming, threats, constant abuse and disrespect by management is beyond anything I experienced anywhere else in over 15 years, the turn over in this department is 40 - 50%, but nothing ever changes.  No one is happy and everyone is unduly stressed and even scared and intimidated by the horrible management that makes the stressful workload even more unbearable.

job_title: Senior Director in New York, NY
pros: Large organization with many locations and departments.  Many opportunities to move around and work in new areas.   Exceptional benefits.  Many exceptional front-line staff, but limited by union and/or culture of fear instilled from the top.   CEO has a progressive vision - unfortunately, there is a huge gap between the culture/implementation and his vision.  Work/life balance is reasonable.
cons:
Focus is purely on creating an external perception of excellence when reality is quite the opposite.  While there are many opportunities to advance, the positions are often given to the "climbers/self-promoters or sycophants" and not to the high performers.  Generally poor to average (at best) performance on quality and service  Union mindset runs the place - creates environment where mediocrity is not only acceptable, but also rationalized.  Culture is rife with fear - different viewpoints are not welcomed.  No communication as to how NS as a whole is actually doing
Generally poor performance on quality and service -

job_title: Clinical Practice Plan Representative in Lake Success, NY
pros: They have numerous positions and if you know the right person you can move around.
cons: The job I applied for is overwhelming. Majority of the staff is stressed out and dislikes many aspects of the role. Theres like 20 different programs you have to work from and the training feels like i’m back in college times 20. To make matters worse the job description is way different than what I thought I was applying for. Now let’s get into benefits. If you work in an office you get 2 weeks PTO including sick. Yes you heard that right 2 WEEKS for everything. So not only does there staff look overwhelmed but they only get 2 weeks out of 52 weeks in a year to travel or get sick. This is completely unacceptable. They don’t even get floating holidays.  The compensation for all the things the want you to do sucks. Healthcare is ok if you go to all Northwell doctors or participating providers. I read the reviews before I applied and I thought I was walking into something great but was left disappointed. I’m considering going back to my old job.  The class that I was training with all feel the same way.

job_title: Medical Records Coder in Lynbrook, NY
pros: I was hired as a Northwell employee (Medical Records Coder)  but reported to Optum management. I DO NOT have a single positive comment about Optum.
cons: A company called Optummanages Northwell's billing and coding. I was hired as a Northwell coder however reported to Optum management. Optum DOES NOT follow nor promote Northwell's (alleged because I never got to see it) culture and mission; compassion, respect, responsibility and caring not only for its patients but its employees.  That "made for us" does not apply to Northwell's Optum employees. The Optum management at the Lynbrook location were unprofessional, unethical and uncaring. This made for a very toxic and hostile environment.

job_title: Marketing Specialist in New Hyde Park, NY
pros: Pays well for your hard work; moving up to better yourself is greatly encouraged - they want you to continue learning which carries a positive effect in your personal growth as well. Higher ups are always talking about growing with/within the company - and they actually mean it. The teamwork is real and you're made to feel as if you are a part of an ever growing system. Keeping their staff healthy is a big initiative. Best part - Benefits are amazing!
cons: Lack of diversity within corporate offices make it difficult. It's a bit heartbreaking to look around and not see this wonderful opportunity being taken advantage of by a diverse crowd. HR is horrible at finding proper talent that isn't medical staff. Lack of proper training (outside of Medical staff) within hospitals & satellites make it difficult to do your job well sometimes. Sadly it is a clique & you have to win your way in. Just like any place, you have to figure a way to make yourself indispensable.

job_title: CBO Employee in Katonah, NY
pros: Pay is at the higher rate
cons: Human Resources and the Directors claim to be on the employees side when issues arise.  Absolute lies. I heard that the upper management states that the horrible moral is the cause of some employees that are or were there. Basically stated that when they leave the moral gets better with new employees.  During this meeting it was said that the upper management laughed about it.  They think it is all a joke and not taking a look at the reason why employees are not happy, in which comes down to the decisions of the upper management. Employees that have chosen to leave left for a reason and the high turn over employees is just disgusting.  In the month of Aug, five people have left and more will be leaving. This company does not have the word happy place on it. There are reasons and those reason are covered up and fingers are pointed at the employees not at the true reasons at hand.

review_title: Hearst Critical Care Fellowship is an unparalleled opportunity for aspiring critical care nurses
job_title: Registered Nurse in Manhasset, NY
pros:
-abilily to move within the system (Manhasset-LIJ-Southside-14 hospitals)
-job stability
-opportunity to move from bedside nursing to management / educator / clinician coordinator
- competitive salary and PTO package
-free indoor parking
-tertiary care center so Manhasset gets the highest acuity patients transferred in
-excellent orientation program (Hearst Critical Care Fellowship)
cons:
-cuts in ancillary staff (patient care tech, unit secretary) have shifted more of the non-clinical duties to the nursing staff
-you're on your own when it comes to meals --> rarely get normal lunch (1 hour UNPAID deducted whether you eat or not?!) or required break time because there is no dedicated staff for relief
-small incremental cost-of-living raises (0-1.5%) are sometimes replaced with "lump" sum (ie your base rate doesn't improve)

review_title: Good healthcare. But room for improvement...
job_title: Assistant Director in Great Neck, NY
pros: Good benefits. Nice commute for people living in Long Island. Communication via the intranet, known as Healthport, is good.
cons: It is really hard to get a job at NSLIJ. The HR dept (Talent Acquisition) needs more improvement and quicker turnaround time. They have rolled out this electronic system called Taleo but I do not think it is helpful. The resumes don't even make it to the hiring managers timely. Benefits are decent except for the way time off is done. There is a lumping of sick and vacation time into fixed number of paid time off (PTO). Parking can be difficult.

review_title: Northshore LIJ - overall a great place to work.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Melville, NY
pros:
Northshore LIJ Health System is very large, aggressively growing (and yes,  there  is a certain amount of inevitable confusion that results from this) organization.  I have had the opportunity to work with many different groups and people and overall, its a great place to work for the following reasons:

- Senior Management are generally smart people and accountable for their decisions.
- They unrelentingly invest in making their business better.
- People who work there are generally smart, honest people.  Yes every organization has politics and sometimes this can be an issue but I've never met anyone there who had a bad attitude or that I didn't believe was trying to improve health care.
- They are flexible and reasonable.
- Great people.
cons: - Some Long Island facilities were hard to get to and not very well provisioned.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Great Neck, NY
pros: The company provides great benefits, highly pays corporate employees, and gives many incentives. There's many opportunities to move within.
cons: To get those incentives, be prepared to work all hours, forge "fake" relationships, deal with politics 24/7 and have zero balance between your personal and professional life. They pay you well but expect you to live and breathe the work. And the work never slows down. It was utterly impossible to keep up - the minute you accomplished something Management piled on more work. No boundaries.

review_title: New single aircraft program setting a foundation for expansion
job_title: Flight Paramedic in Islip, NY
pros: Probably one of the best paying air medical jobs in the US, but it is situated in one of the most expensive places to live on earth. Benefits are excellent, along with more time off than I know what to do with.
cons: Rotating nights and days which might be a negative for some. I like changing it up for a few weeks a time. This is a new program so if you like or don't like how something is, wait a while. Change is guaranteed. Joint venture with Yale New Haven, which is mostly a good thing, but two large health systems take significantly longer than one to make change or for capital purchases to be approved.

review_title: The Core Lab is run by Idiots!!!
job_title: Phlebotomist in Lake Success, NY
pros: Pretty decent salary, excellent benefits (when you can find time to use them!)
cons: The atmosphere is a little oppressive. So much favoritism and hypocrisy from the top to the bottom. Bad behavior is rewarded it seems because they fire the good ones and keep the rotten apples! Management even seems like they are just there collecting their paychecks...is really sad because I  really enjoyed working there. Anything mentioned to management in confidence, doesn't stay there!. Too many Indians not enough good chiefs! I ignored the high-turnover and applied anyway and lived to regret it!

review_title: Happy to work here, wish some things would change
job_title: Registered Nurse in Manhasset, NY
pros: Paid time off accrues quickly, salary is great, health insurance is $40 per paycheck or free if you do four of the "wellness credits" you get to see any northwell affiliated doctor or urgent care with no copay. Hospital is clean and well maintained, improvements are always being made. Frequent opportunities for growth. Cash bonuses at the end of the year for certifications or clinical ladders.
cons: In my unit people never leave so it's hard to gain seniority over others, which messes with vacations and potential to switch from nights to days. Hospital seems to mostly care about Press Ganey's a.k.a. Patient reviews, we end up being more of maids and butlers than nurses. The customer is always right! Really?! This is a healthcare facility not a hotel. Unfortunately that's the way the corporation is going and is little people don't have much to say about it.

job_title: PRACTICE OFFICE ASSOCIATE in Mount Kisco, NY
pros:
people are nice (most of them) 
doctors are nice (most of them)
cons: The office is totally dysfunctional. Upper management make up the rules as they go along often times contradicting themselves. The director locks herself in her office most of the day and is clueless as to what is going on outside. Everyone is overworked. Before my arrival at this office 5 people walked off the job. I'm not surprised.  The staffs motto about the place is "its lose / lose, even when your right your wrong". So they really don't care about the job they do. If you want to work like a robot, go there. The lunchroom is so small you are literally eating on top of one another. The office chairs are held together with duct tape. Cramped office yet not enough staff to handle the work load.

job_title: General Manager in Manhasset, NY
pros: There are still some good people who are loyal and put the success of the health system first, over their personal advancement.
cons: Terribly infested with individuals who value loyalty to themselves by their staff over dedication to the success of the health system. You WILL be punished by some people in upper management for doing the right thing according to stated corporate values...or for just having values.   The culture is rapidly becoming noxious in some key departments: much back stabbing, little helping others and much ecstatic adulation when other employees "appear" to run into issues; much favoritism and a lot of pointing the finger at others.   Also, it appears job security is slipping away - MANY people act as if you can be terminated for anything at any time.

job_title: Medical Assistant in Stamford, CT
pros: They give a good amount of computer training. My coworkers and direct supervisor are all very friendly and encouraging. Always very helpful when it gets busy, even if it isn't their direct responsibility.
cons: The doctors are jerks. I understand that things happened to be changing a lot (definitely not by their choice) but dont take that out on your MAs. Also don't blame your MA for your schedule running late when you didn't bother to look at or acknowledge that the patients were the ones arriving 20-30 minutes late. The doctors also never gave me time to do an intake, I just put patients in rooms all day.

review_title: Good place to work for part-timers
job_title: Billing Associate in Nassau, NY
pros: Large health system with benefits for part timers working 20+ hours per week. Very good communications from the CEO and executive management.  Organization focused on best in class practices and standards.  They take feedback very seriously and want to do a good job.  Good place to work.
cons: HR difficult to get in touch with.  You could wait forever on the phone.  This is something that needs improving and they should make this a corporate initiative.   I have had a few HR related issues and it took several tries to get any information.

job_title: Vice President in Great Neck, NY
pros:
Exceptional benefits
Lots of options for different locations, different parts of healthcare
Could be a truly great organization given our unique size and footprint
cons:
Nepotism and patronage (e.g. neighbors, dentist's son) are rampant throughout, especially for senior leaders.
There are a lot of good people with good ideas, but ideas are not welcomed.   Presenting alternative views in front of many of our leaders is suicidal.
We believe our own press too much and do not look at how we are actually doing (poor patient satisfaction, poor Leapfrog)
Taking on way too much risk with health insurance, doctors, more hospitals...now maybe Brooklyn - seriously.
Union employees are treated more favorably than non-union (Optum is an example).

job_title: Accounting Clerk in New York, NY
pros: 75000 employed  the name
cons: Overworked,  pto terrible, benefits expensive, dead end positions, people who are promoted are relatives and spouses its not what you know but who you know many unqualified, people with talent overlooked. People are not recognized, favoritism, ppl who speak spanish supervisor who speaks spanish in front of you. They fire ppl at the dropp of a hate 250 come in every Thursday to new beginnings. 15 year emploee fired one year from retirement. The union side cust service all relatives I have watched women destoyed while relatives are promoted. I have watched a director tell 2 women they dont comprehend. Cust service not easy union in bed with management.  They make you sign things about transgender  even if you are a religious  catholic.  Absolutely no regard for people. The organization is too big h.r. rep is a joke ice cold at town meetings, . No salary advances no help nothing if you neef help financially.

review_title: One of the best jobs in EMS
job_title: Paramedic in Syosset, NY
pros: Very progressive thinking toward patient care.  North Shore CEMS puts a good amount of trust in it;s paramedics, and as such we are able to operate with somewhat more freedom than other places I have worked.  Also very generous amount of time off, benefits are fantastic, and pay is near the top of the field.  In addition to regular income, they do matching contributions to 403(b), which adds up to quite a bit more pay, up to 5% on top of my contributions.
cons: Only paid for 37.5 hours per week (I have never seen this before in the EMS field.)  Also, though not really a downside, North Shore's dedication to excellence can make it a difficult place to work for people coming from a less demanding environment.  They give us a lot, but they expect a lot back.  Seems fair to me.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Melville, NY
pros: There is room for advancement within the Northwell IT department, if you work for it.  The pay is pretty decent compared to other positions locally
cons: There is a strong sense of politics within the department and it is very "cliquey ", which makes it very hard for new employees.  Also I have seen way too many people get promoted or placed into higher positions that they do not belong because senior management are afraid to fire/reprimand people, or to put people in their place and not appease cry babies who think they deserve something because their position does not exist any longer after a hospital take over.

job_title: Analyst in Flagstaff, AZ
pros: Good Salary and depending on when hired benefits.
cons:
Terrible and often managers who do not know how to manage with limited knowledge of the system you are working on.  Very bad communication from one department to another or even within the same team. Glass ceiling for women. Long hours and often overtime at the last minute. Tight deadlines and are expected to work on many things at once, only to be re-directed many times during the course of a week or even day. With required on-call, will often be called at all hours of the day or night to resolve computer problems with little or no compensation.
Employees are often treated  with disrespect by manament and very bad Human Resources department.
Take any other position you can get unless you are a glutton for punishment.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Hyde Park, NY
pros: Various incentives to be healthy. Good benefits.  In certain areas they do promote innovation and recognition for many things across all departments.  Training is often. CEO is usually visible. Friendly with anyone that will approach him.
cons: Those cons are system wide, my issue in in the inpatient medical coding department. There is a lack of communication, constant change in management. Very little transparency. Very little if any resolution for issues related to the above.   The pay for inpatient coders is well below the average and no real answers as to why or if that will be fixed.  WAY to much favoritism.  This depts values are not inline with the companies on a whole.   We seem disconnected from the hospital in general.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Manhasset, NY
pros: Many nice co-workers, in a unit that works hard and mostly well together.  Was able to negotiate a good salary.  Enthusiastic boss who seemed to share goals, at least when interviewing.
cons: Bureaucracy is so large, it's impenetrable, and impossible to get a straight answer never mind get anything changed.  The EMR system is horrible.  The system is many mini-systems very tenuously linked, specialty silos are alive and well, and rarely have meaningful interaction between them.   Benefits are OK as long as you don't mind going to the doctor where you work.  You will wait 6 years to be vested in the retirement plan.

review_title: 'We are all in this together' just an illusion at Long Island Jewish Hospital>
job_title: Medical Technologist in Manhasset, NY
pros: It's close to home and some of the union benefits are good.
cons: Low salaries for union employees and a complete lack of morale.  LIJ now has an anti union mentality which makes for  a very hostile environment.  There is no chance for advancement,  top heavy in management,  not enough motivated people to do the actual patient care work while supervisors and managers spend all their time in nonproductive meetings.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: LOL could not give even one there are absolutely NONE.
cons: We all know that any positive review posted here is from HR or upper management. NS-LIJ was and is still the worst experience of my career and I'm sure many will agree. Avoid Patient Accounts at ALL costs unless you enjoy an abusive hostile environment!. HR is a joke, unresposive and turns away from issues and then of course there's the inability to transfer throughout the health system so you are stuck in a mindless, stagnant position in a dept where you are timed when you goto the bathroom and reprimanded for talking. Yes, really. When hurricane Sandy hit and the office was closed due to no electricity you had to use your PTO in order to get paid. Just a disgrace. Management there is a horror and in the real world outside of their bubble they would never survive. Just an inhumane environment like a prison. Don't even think about it I urge you to look elsewhere!

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in New Hyde Park, NY
pros: Helping patients, contributing to their well being.
cons: Inability to take a lunch break, not being able to finish work in 8 hr period then not being paid for the extra time worked and lunch break deducted from pay check. Belittlement, and down talking by management. Working as an LPN but doing the CNAs work and acting charge on my own without any other help. Doing CNA work because they are on lunch break while i dont have enough time to take a break, or end up leaving late and not getting paid for it.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Lake Success, NY
pros: Northwell Health is an innovative, progressive place to work and I'm proud to be an employee here. We're a diverse organization that gives employees a valued voice and constantly encourages us to be healthy by introducing new programs.  We are the largest private employer in NYS which says something about our amazing CEO Michael Dowling and what he's trying to accomplish in rasing the standard of care.  My job isn't a normal 9-5, it takes hard work and is highly rewarding and that's ok becuase I'm made for this.
cons: It's a very political organization and sometimes hard to navigate.  Certain departments don't have a formal career progression so it's hard to move up within the organization. Benefits are generous but it should be better for a healthcare organization.

job_title: Housekeeper in Flagstaff, AZ
pros: The people you work with who believe in what they do matter what area or job title they hold. Northwell Health overall is an amazing establishment to work for. With a heap of opportunity for advancement.
cons: Upper management has a Jim Crow mentality, if they do not like you they will sabotage your character. There is no one of color in upper mgmt. only a sprinkle of tokens. There is no true leadership in Northwell @Forest Hills.  The leadership there is “NOT MADE FOR THIS” they are not what Northwell Health is represents, they are not what Mr.Dowling stands for!!

job_title: Mental Health Resource Coordinator in Flagstaff, AZ
pros: Very lgbtq friendly, fantastic benefits, work-life balance is on-point.  I was able to march in Long Beach's pride parade and I got to meet so many other lgbtq employees and allies that work for Northwell, it was a great time. Speaking of colleagues, everyone in my department is awesome, including my supervisors.
cons: Only con that comes to mind is salary. Mental health professionals do not get paid as much as medical staff. Whether it be to lack of funding, the stigma that's still attached, etc. I have a Master's degree and post-graduate work and I don't make half the salary my lovely RN counterparts do.

review_title: The Best Small Community Hospital, extensive services, great location, management  andstaff
job_title: Manager in Flagstaff, AZ
pros: Friendly, family-oriented staff with superior retention--a place to start or extend a career, definitely a place to stay and retire from; Excellent benefits and accessible, supportive HR staff; Beautiful environment next to Rockefeller State Park on the shores of the Hudson River, many recent upgrades and renovations to buildings and grounds; Teaching hospital with multiple learning and career growth opportunities; Supportive and involved community; multiple in and outpatient services always growing; Supportive and involved management and CEO who values staff above all; new partner in expanding Northwell Health system with additional supports and staff-oriented philosophy; excellent results from Joint Commission and DOH surveys in 2016.
cons: As in any healthcare environment, uncertainty of governmental supports, ever-changing regulations and oversight.

review_title: Physician Partner Practice managements runs amok!
job_title: PRACTICE OFFICE ASSOCIATE in Islandia, NY
pros: Northwell hospitals seem like a much better place to work.
cons: Northwell does not intervene in their physician partner practices. The PTO is awful for office staff and our supervisors force us to use PTO if they decide to close early for the doctor’s dinner parties or computer maintenance. The supervision is terrible and there is no room for growth. I’ve been applying to positions in which I am qualified for about a year, and I haven’t heard a thing. Human Resources is clearly uneducated and they tell your supervisors everything you tell them (in a supposed confidence)  with no remorse which makes the work environment really uncomfortable.

review_title: Peconic Bay Medical Center: Great staff—unacceptable RN to patient ratios
job_title: Registered Nurse in Riverhead, NY
pros: Some of the nicest, most conscientious, people you will ever work with. Great benefits and growth opportunities.
cons: The workload. RN to patient ratio consistently over the contracted ratio for the unit—at times, dangerously so. Most people don’t bother to file protest of assignment, at least that I’ve seen.  “Too busy.” Are all units like this? I really don’t know. You hit the ground running. Ask about this in interview and if the answer you get is unacceptable, keep looking. On some units, staff is mostly new, inexperienced nurses, which they occasionally have an experienced “resource nurse” on staff to help remedy.

job_title: Pediatric Nurse Practitioner in Ozone Park, NY
pros: Many professional development opportunities. Great team to work with.
cons:
Off-site clinics have little managerial support or oversight. Programs such as lactation support and lactation rooms are not readily available  in off-site clinics. 

I left as a lactating mother. I requested that my site manager block my patient schedule for my pump breaks two months before my return from my maternity leave, but they refused to block my schedule and told me to pump during my lunch break in my patient exam room. I was frequently unable to take lunch breaks due to our patient load. The failure to block my schedule resulted in backed up patients and my stress level being unmanageable.

review_title: Customer Service Rep. at Patient Access Services
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Melville, NY
pros: Depending on what team you are on, good vibes and people. Lenient depending on who is your supervisor.
cons: PTO accumulation sucks. If you have a bad supervisor might get denied. A lot of the directors or higher-ups seem to do nothing all day and look down on your job. You get talked to like dirt by patients on a daily. Bathroom time is monitored 6 minutes of personal time per day. 45 minute lunch 15 minute break... goes fast considering all the work you put in. Not enough support from the practices. When a patient is in an emergency situation and in need of immediate medical attention it is a pain trying to get the doctors or nurses to answer their phones.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Hyde Park, NY
pros: Northwell is a great place to work! I've been here over 5 years and within those years, I've had 3 promotions and a ton of other opportunities that have helped me grow my career. Working for such a large health system provides employees with a lot of exposure. The leadership is great and they're truly invested in their employees. Programs such as high potential where 20-25 high achievers are selected annually and provided with one year leadership training is a perfect example of how invested the executive leadership team is in fostering their employees.
cons: Since the health system is so large, employees tend to have niche skills and knowledge. A smaller health system would allow employees to gain expertise in more than just one area.

job_title: Registered Nurse, Critical Care in New York, NY
pros: Competitive salary,  great benefits,  good work culture.  I have worked for Northwell for 3 years so far and have really enjoyed it.
cons: My only complaint is that the company is expanding so quickly that sometimes it feels as though  too much focus is being placed on expansion, and not enough on improving  quality of work life.

review_title: North Shore-LIJ was once the place to be!
job_title: Coordinator in Manhasset, NY
pros: Working at the hospital was great because it was like its very own community. Everybody knew each other and it was a very nice environment. Pay was decent, benefits were great and you had a generous amount of PTO.
cons: The hospital ended up selling several departments to a West Coast based company and the benefits they were offering were horrible so that is why I looked elsewhere. As long as you are working for Northwell Health, formerly known as North Shore, you are golden.

job_title: Sonogram Tech in Nassau, NY
pros: Ummmmm, it's all good until you're not needed, then it's made impossible to continue working with integrity, company breaks you down....
cons:
No one listens to staff. No compensation for a job well done, as of now, 2014 we all got a raise across the board, 2015 raise will be merit based.
A ceiling that doesn't allow for movement, or more $$$
Company expects employees 100%, good employees get worn down, bad employees or missing employees get rewarded and there is NO ONE TO TELL ABOUT IT!
No job security from company, under the guise of the law, they demote employees at will, instead of firing... Making it impossible to keep the position at the limited hours!

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Lenox Hill is a very welcoming and warm environment that feels small and intimate even though it is very large and complex offering the most advanced technology and expertise.  From the Northwell Orientation (Beginnings) to the on site orientation, everything is perfect.  The people are the magic of this place.  There is true compassion for patients, visitors and colleagues.  Although the hospital is part of a much larger System, the strength of the individual hospital is supported and promoted.
cons: There are a tremendous number of resources available in the System but many of them are only available on Long Island.  The System is working to regionalize some of these programs to better support the needs of the Northwest Region.

review_title: Toxic work environment, poor culture, no diversity in senior management
job_title: Manager in Manhasset, NY
pros: Benefits are good, compensation is average
cons: Poor work/life balance, no support from senior leadership, little diversity in senior leadership, everyone seems hostile and overwhelmed, treated like a machine not a human

review_title: It was the worst job experience of my life.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Hyde Park, NY
pros:
Salary was OK.
Benefits were great, the only thing I miss about this place.
cons:
Leadership- They seemed to have forgotten they are doctors.   They don't care about anyone patients or otherwise.
Work-life balance- My boss would email me at 3-4 am and expect a response. I was reprimanded when I responded at 8. 

I was not a doctor and was not supposed to be on call.

review_title: NSLIJ is a great place to work, however the Technology area is riddled with poor management and some nepotism.
job_title: IT Senior Manager in Melville, NY
pros: Good salaries for Long Island. Very passive environment. Great job security, always room for lateral growth if you're in the top 20% and are motivated.
cons: Poor management across IT areas. Lax environment leads to top third of employees doing 2/3rds of the work. Nepotism runs wild in IT, although recently thats getting cleaned up. No accountability where its due, usually low team on the pole is left holding the accountability bag for another teams failures.

job_title: Assistant Director/HIM in Sleepy Hollow, NY
pros:
Working here at Phelps since 2007 has been one of my most rewarding career experiences.
I have learned a great deal that has not only aided in my career but also in my personal life. The diverse use of technology has been useful and enlightening. The staff here at Phelps operates as a family. We are a team in all we do. We laugh; we cry; we help each other. It truly is a wonderful place to work, to seek medical care or have some great coffee!
cons: I have none to report. Of course you have some days that are busier than others. But that is life.

review_title: I'm proud to be part of Northwell Health
job_title: Account Supervisor in New York, NY
pros: I have been with Northwell Health for 7 years now. As a working mother of 4 Northwell has been my biggest supporter juggling my career and my family.  My manager is very understanding in regard of any events I have for my kids  as I tried to get involved in their life as much as possible. This kind of support is very hard to find in NY. As a proud mother of an Army son, I'm so very honor that Northwell also support active, veteran and their family.
cons: Starting as a clerk and as a supervisor role that I'm currently now, nothing negative I can say about Northwell. Overall I'm so honor and proud being part of Northwell Health. I made for this :)

job_title: Accessioner in New Hyde Park, NY
pros:
Good benefits 
Decent people but also very lazy people who think the world owes them something because they have been there longer but cannot process anywhere near the amount of patients newer employees do.
cons:
Awful upper management 
Little to no communication about what is going on in the lab
Terrible scheduling- when i asked for certain days off it is "expected" by management to return the favor so to speak.  They make you feel like you owe them something for requesting days off even if its months in advance.

job_title: Registered Nurse in New Hyde Park, NY

cons: You don’t always feel heard. The job can be very intense sometimes. And you don’t get paid for being the charge nurse even thought it is on top of a regular patient assignment.

job_title: Taleo Business Analyst in Manhasset, NY
pros: Good Benefits, 6.5 weeks vacation, 200 a month for insurance for a family of four, good 401 k plan, good location on long island
cons:
I am a former employee. I have a above average education. I had to apply to close to 100 roles to get 2 interviews. I finally got a role in an administrative function performing Business analysis. Benefits are great. 

Advancement is sub par. Only people in their 600 community drive building get promoted the most. Otherwise, even though employees can apply online, your chances are slim to none you will get anything. Roles are earmarked for internal candidates as soon as they are posted. It is just a formality so they don't get legal action against them.

You either need to know someone or  have a relative working there to get a new internal role. That's if your manager doesn't sabotage your chances. Also, hr wants you to tell your boss you are applying to roles as opposed to when you are actually being considered. 

In addition, it is hard to move around because if you get regular increases, it prices you out of other jobs you would want internally. Again, if you know someone, they will restructure the role to say manager in the title, so you can get the job at a higher rate. 

For that reason, you need to apply to outside companies. Once you announce you found a new job to your manager, then comes damage control. This entails bad mouthing the employee so that other employees don't get the idea to leave as well. 

They are also good about adding new practices at a quick pace but never add on new staff to support them. This ultimately means dumping more and more work/responsibilities to their existing employees while not recognizing them in new titles or salary increases. 

They also announced over a year ago that they would create an internal job site just for employees. They still haven't created it and when you ask hr about it, they ignore you.

Management is more self absorbed about themselves and who they are married too.

job_title: Talent Acqusition Specialist in New Hyde Park, NY
pros:
Northwell Health is the largest, and one of the best employers in New York State.  If you're looking to get into the Health system, Northwell is where you want to look since they now own most of the major hospitals in Nassau & Queens.  Lots of growth opportunities and the potential to move into other departments (usually for non-medical roles).  

Here's some of the major perks to being a Talent Acquisition Specialist:

* Lots of flexibility - you are given a laptop and a phone and can work remote, either from home or on-site at one of your "client" locations somewhat often

* Strong team mentality - there's rarely any competition other than standard friendly rivalries. 

* Northwell pays relatively well for internal corporate recruiting but could be better 

* Organized teams with dedicated individuals servicing specific roles within client locations means you don't get the "mayonnaise" effect of feeling spread too thin managing too many portfolios (though that doesn't mean you won't be insanely busy)

* Lots of training opportunities and the occasional team-building outing encourages friendships and partnerships with your colleagues.
cons:
The size of the Talent Acquisition Department is one of its biggest flaws.  Everyone is a number.  While you typically do get personal treatment from your manager(s), ultimately you are just one recruiter in an office full of 30 others, so the most attention you'll get is when something went wrong or if you already have a good friendship/relationship with your manager(s).

* Turnover is too high for a role like this.  Great contractors are hired all the time, and rarely ever get brought on board permanently.  Most are let go early because they aren't performing, but that's mainly due to...

* Poor training.  I remember when I was trained, I sat in a room with one of my colleagues while they spoke about how to do things...many times a day over the course of a week.  It was frustratingly boring and things haven't changed - they take new hires into a room and sit down and talk about how to do things.  I've delivered said training before and have had more than one trainee nearly fall asleep from boredom.  Having done the same myself, I sympathized.  That's STILL how we do it today.

* People get burnt out and check out.  That's really the only reason people get terminated is they just get so burnt out from the monotony of the role that they just stop caring.  Morale is LOW. The fact that we have...

*...way too many requisitions assigned to a single person has a lot to do with that.  The average specialist has anywhere from 50 - 100+ requsitions assigned to them.  The same burden is often put on new hires and they are unprepared for the extent of this, despite whatever background they may have come from.

* Hot headed hiring managers make it miserable.  Of course your position is urgent...EVERY position is urgent in the hospital system!  They don't care about any other location's position though, only theirs...so that argument is rendered moot.  The hiring managers have a tendency to get impatient, angry and often try to go around you or over your head to your manager.  Seeing that we are required to put a message in our e-mail signature encouraging people to contact our managers for any reason, the complaints come in steadily enough.

* Pay rates for positions are adequate but on the low end of the spectrum.  We are told to offer the lowest pay rate for the position, and only can go to the mid range after a lengthy, exhausting process of appealing and trying to convince management why the candidate is worth more than the bare minimum.  It's a challenge and sometimes goes to the highest levels of the organization.  Forget ever offering the high end salary range...it doesn't happen.

* Rules and regulations differ from one hospital to the next, and the process for dealing with the different union, non-union, exempt, special and whatnot situations gets tiresome. 

* Creating offers is a lengthy, often frustrating process that requires lots of cross-checking of archaic excel spreadsheets.  Northwell desperately needs a system to manage this. 

* Political environment is a bit too blatant - we were recently "strongly encouraged" at a Town Hall event to vote for a specific candidate in the recent presidential election.  We were told that voting for her opponent would be "stupid" and "moronic".  Cardboard cut out "standees" and propaganda around the office of said candidate was distracting and frustrating.

job_title: Senior Management in Manhasset, NY
pros: Very low work output expectation, very stable employment, good pay & benefits, very little supervision, lots of engineers to talk to. Management more concerned with not being found responsible and being able to "know" what's happening instead of leading any actual serious improvement or preventative measures. All the way up to the Sr Director level can't substantially reward or discipline anyone.  I actually know someone who fell asleep at his desk and still received a mediocre review.  I've had managers tell me they'd love to replace several people but they are prevented from taking action due to conflict of what's best for the outsourcer monetarily vs what's good for the client. job_title: Paramedic II in Syosset, NY
pros: The ONLY pro. $31 hourly rate for a paramedic who sufficiently brown noses his/her way to up to paramedic II. The time off is nice as well, but it is in line with what all hospital based EMS agencies offer.
cons:
Forming a list is neccessary.
1) There are two females and one minority who have managed to crack the barrier up beyond a grunt in a department with 400+ employees.

2)You will always come last. 16 hour work days with no bathroom break or meal is typical.

3)incompetant schedulers require a total redo of everyones schedule every 6 to 12 months.

4)Managements answers to employees concerns. "....we have a stack of resumes this thick."

5)NO reliable means of communicating IMPORTANT information. ie When induced hypothermia protocols began, we didnt have coolers or cold fluid. Then one day, out of nowhere, with no comunication we do they are installed.

7)You have to put in for seniority based pto 6 months in advance and then it takes 4 months to actually approve or deny it.

8)The promotion to Paramedic II is for experienced Paramedics. It is routinely given to dispatchers with ZERO experience on an ambulance as a paramedic.

9)If you disagree with a manager at any time, your career is all but over. You will have eyes on you non stop. Look for another job.

10)Management operates with the assumption that you are the laziest stupidest creature alive.

11)Why are people with the same job duties paid up to $10K/year less even when they have more experience in some instances?

12)This departments has probably the highest turn over rate in the entire health system. People are hired and fired constantly

13)Requires mentioning again. If you are not a white male, born and raised and currently living in Nassau or Suffolk counties you will not fit in or be promoted. 

I am not a FORMER employee. I am a current employee, and in good standing.

review_title: LIJ has a hectic discharge process
job_title: RN Case Manager in New Hyde Park, NY
pros: The case management department at LIJ has great leadership-very supportive and caring regarding the hectic work flow. Team players and supportive of one another. You are a respected member of a team. In this department there is a lot of autonomy.
cons:
The salary at LIJ for nurses is terrible. Ive worked at this site for some time and the salary on the floor and in the case management department varies so much from person to person it makes me very suspicious. The discharge process makes discharge planning almost impossible! The various medical teams (PA's, residents, NP's, Attending's, etc) utilize ineffective communication when it comes to the needs of the patients at the time of discharge. They don't care about the psycho-social aspect of treating a person, once they are medically stable they want the patients out and neglect their ability to manage at home. They never consult case managers until the day of discharge and the paperwork is NEVER complete in time. The work load for case managers is currently so stretched due to open positions that we don't get to properly assess everyone. We also do utilization reviews. Physicians and residents are nasty and rude. They have no clue of the difference between a case manager vs. a social worker.

Mon-Fri schedule is terrible for such a busy work flow. No time off for your personal life.

Nursing administration hires their "own" instead of qualified people. They are on-boarding young inexperience nurse managers with little experience. They do not discipline nurse managers when they have multiple complaints. The nurse managers and the CNO are out to get staff nurses. Never have been very supportive of their nursing staff.  

Absolutely no diversity in nursing administration and management at LIJ.

The benefits are excellent and I haven't been here long enough to speak about raises and so forth, but the starting salary for my position is at or above the market rate, so I believe that I am being compensated fairly.
